text: hello everyone I'm super excited to be
here today my name is Emma I'm a
software engineer at Spotify and yeah
I've been working on Backstage over the
last five years uh on different parts
and I'm super happy to be here today to
talk about
accessibility so let's take a few steps
back first uh we are all in here on a
mission to make backstage the industry
leading developer portal right because
we love and care about happy developers
and and I believe if we want to get
there we need to build backstage with an
inclusive mindset and what do I mean by
that well I think we need to build and
test backstage um based on input and
needs from a wide set of users by doing
so we will improve accessibility and
thereby increase the number of develop
happy developers as well so um yeah last
year we paired up with our amazing
accessibility team at Spotify on a
mission to make backstage a little bit
more more useful for
everyone so I'm here today to talk about
the audit process that we went through
uh but also um present a couple of
actions that you can take already today
to improve accessibility of your
backstage
plugins so this has been a three-step
process for us uh we realized pretty
quickly as we started off this work that
it would be impossible for us to audit
all the plugins out there uh so we
decided to scope the work to Backstage
core features as well as the commercial
plugins we have the second step we
wanted to take was to run the automated
Audits and third step the manual audits
which is still in progress at the moment
but why do we want to include both of
them maybe you ask and um the reason for
that is while automated audits is a
great start for you to kind of start
identify issues quickly but it only
captures captures a low amount of them
so it's super important to let users
actually walk through the product so
that you can catch more issues to um
solve as I mentioned we're still um in
progress with the manual one so I'll
focus in on the automated audits
today so yeah we used Lighthouse Dev
tools to conduct our automated Audits
and and on the screen here you can see
uh that I've navigated to a backstage
entity Page open up the dev tools as
well as navigated to
Lighthouse Lighthouse is a tool to
improve General web quality of web pages
but we use it specifically for
accessibility and by using lighthouse we
were able to identify 106 accessibility
issues across these plugin where today
we have resolved around 76% of them and
um yeah as you can see you're able to
configure Lighthouse um based on which
mode you want to use which device you
want to run on and um which
categories and then you click on analyze
page load and it will generate a report
for you and what's really good with this
was not just that that it identified
issues for us but it also linked out to
additional information of how to resolve
the issue and also the E user impact it
had so among these uh 106 issues that we
identified a couple of the common issues
that I wanted to lift up here today was
uh for example not having enough color
contrast um which means that elements
blend in together and it's super
difficult for people for example with
low vision or being colorblind to
actually distinguish the elements from
each other two other common issues that
we capture were um that the HTML wasn't
structure properly which means that when
you're using a screen reader it doesn't
get announced to you correctly which
means that you can't navigate through
the
page we also of course wanted to make
sure that the issues that we fixed
didn't return into the product so what
we did was that we added CI checks to
the backstage open S Source repo uh to
make sure that we were running these
checks uh on all the plugins that we
configured to run on uh we were using
Lighthouse there as well um but this
also means that we do not um introduce
new issues but also the issues that we
have fixed doesn't return much since we
added the CI checks on the open source
uh main repo we have also seen uh checks
being added on the micro side which is
amazing and this is all because of this
amazing
Community okay three ways you can do uh
to uh improve accessibility on your
backstage plugins uh first thing you can
obviously as well run Lighthouse Dev
tools or Lighthouse CLI on your plug-in
as you develop them which means that you
will catch these issues early
on second thing that you can do is I
mentioned that we already configured
backstage main repo to have to run these
checks inci so you can add your plugins
if it lives inside the main repo to this
configuration so it will automatically
run on your plugins as well but if your
plugins live outside the main repository
you can use the CHX we put together with
GitHub actions and move them over to
your repo and if you're not using GitHub
actions as you see a PR Rider you can
also of course um look at the official
Lighthouse documentation to um see which
other ones they have supported um we
have more documentation around this over
at
backstage. do/ accessibility if you uh
want to read
more but maybe you sit here and think
this is all in the development phase why
do we need to go all the way there to
actually start identify issues and if
you were thinking that I'm very happy
because I also wanted to send you off
with some um from my perspective things
that we can do already earlier in in the
process um so from a product research
perspective really make sure that we
include this as part of the requirements
that we create because it all starts
there right and as you are you doing
user testing make sure to include a
diverse set of
users but also put yourself in the shoes
of your users there's uh you can also
use assistive technology there is this
uh keyboard testing template that I
wanted to share with you uh which you
can use to actually walk through the
product with just keyboard um and on uh
the design phase we I wanted to send
this um with you because I got
introduced to this figma annotation kit
a while back uh that lets you annotate
your designs uh with accessibility
labels uh so that when you hand it over
to engineering it's easier to for them
to pick it up so for example should this
be a decorative image or an informative
image so that means you can easier
decide which alternative text we should
use for
example so there is there been a lot of
teams involved in all of this work and
um the backstage Community have picked
up issues and improved this as well so I
just wanted to send a huge thank you to
everyone who have worked on this and uh
yeah thanks for listening into this talk
today and if you have any questions I'm
happy to chat with you throughout the
day as well so thank you so
much thanks thank you Emma any questions
for
Emma okay there you go one more we have
a break after this till
1105 uh thank you for that presentation
I have uh two short questions first have
you found any ways to improve the
backstage default themes while you're
like through your investigations and
second do you think it would be
worthwhile offering more themes to users
like by default to uh adjust for
personal uh
preferences yeah great question so one
of the issues that that I um uh
presented here around the color contrast
so that was actually one of the issues
that we found were around the primary
color that we use for the theme so that
was an update that we did across the
themes which applied to many plugins
right uh so that's one thing uh around
offering different types of themes I
think at least one of the issues that we
have found is on a third party library
that we use for code Snippets um which
comes with a theme that is not
accessibility friendly so that's
probably something that we'll look in
together if we can create a custom theme
for that one to bring into the
project thank you
